awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), Professor Brett VanVeller of the Department of Chemistry at Iowa State University is developing new classes of molecules that can be manipulated with light.  The goal of this research is to use light-sensitive dye molecules to turn chemical reactions on and off.  The systems under development are useful for making functional materials (lithography), synthesizing pharmaceuticals, and understanding biological systems. The education objectives engage public school students in order to cultivate a greater appreciation for how the properties and functions of molecules influence their world. This goal is achieved by developing kits that are distributed at teach the teacher seminars at the local science center.  Facilitating teacher training allows the VanVellar team to broaden the impact of their educational efforts by reaching a broader student audience. 

This research project is to study the effect that environmentally-sensitive excited states have on controlling the efficiency of photo-deprotection reactions. The hypothesis is that environmentally sensitive deactivation of the molecular excited state can be used to selectively turn the photo-deprotection reaction on and off.  The specific objectives of this project include identifying the factors that control solvent-dependent photocleavage as well as identifying the structure-property relationships and excited state dynamics that control oxygen-dependent photocleavage.  The research team also looks for alternative approaches for environmentally-controlled photo-deprotection. Moreover, the research activities are applied to two different classes of photocleavable protection groups, each with a distinct mechanism of photocleavage. The outcomes of this work may expand both the knowledge of environmentally-controlled photo reactions and their applications in advanced manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the Chemical Mechanism, Function, and Properties Program in the Division of Chemistry, and the Office of Strategic Initiatives in the Directorate for Mathematical & Physical Sciences, Prof. Brett VanVeller of Iowa State University has made significant discoveries in both fundamental photochemistry and the ability to access molecular structure that was not previously possible. 

 

One outcome of the project has been a more complete understanding of the behavior of organic molecules upon absorbing a photon of light, entering what is called the excited state. Briefly, the fundamental rules of stability flip before and after absorbing light (Bard’s Rule). An electronic structure that is universally considered stabilizing in the ground state is suddenly destabilizing in the excited state. While often invoked in theoretical descriptions of molecules, real-world experimental examples are rare. With support from this award, one of the first rationalizations of excited state behavior and reactivity was reported, facilitated by detailed visualization of electron structure to improve understanding of the factors involved. 

 

Another outcome of the project has been the development of synthetic methods that exploit sulfur-containing functional groups of molecules for conversion into molecular scaffolds that have not before been explored in biomolecules, perhaps due to a lack of general methods to create them, which our synthetic discoveries resolve. 

 

A final outcome of the project has been the investigation of the potential of a class of photo-stable heterocycles for selective bond cleavage with light. Several discoveries regarding new reactivity were made during the synthesis of these materials, and the potential of these groups that can be activated with light were explored for manipulation of macromolecular entities. 

 

Collectively, the outcomes of this work promise to have broad and positive impact on the fields of photochemistry, biomolecular, and material science. A deeper understanding of the fundamental nature of the energetic forces at play after an organic molecule absorbs a photon of light will inform the design of excited-state processes, reactivity, and the design of new devices. Molecular architectures that have never before been possible in biomolecules can now be accessed and evaluated for their therapeutic potential. Advances in these areas promise to expand the capabilities of material and energy science and drug discovery. This project was also instrumental in the training of PhD and undergraduate level scientists from underrepresented backgrounds.

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2024
Modified by: Brett Vanveller
